question: What accuracy improvements does the ACE method achieve compared to one-stage SOTA methods on CIFAR100-LT with imbalance factor 100?
answer: The ACE method achieves an accuracy improvement of 11.1% compared to the one-stage SOTA method on CIFAR100-LT with an imbalance factor of 100. Baseline accuracy is 38.3%, and ACE achieves 49.4%.
reference: \"Table 1: Top-1 accuracy on CIFAR100-LT-100. ($\\cdot$) shows comparison to the baseline, where \\textcolor{green}{increase} and \\textcolor{red}{decrease} are represented by color. Our ACE is the only one-stage method with performance gain on all groups and of the best over all categories.\"

question: On the ImageNet-LT dataset, how does ACE's performance compare to the baseline when using ResNet-10?
answer: On the ImageNet-LT dataset using ResNet-10, the ACE method achieves a top-1 accuracy of 44.0%, which is 23.1% higher than the baseline accuracy of 20.9%.
reference: \"Table 2: Top-1 accuracy on ImageNetLT and iNaturalist2018. [...] Our ACE has consistent performance gain comparing with other one-stage methods with multiple backbones, and is comparable with multi-stage methods.\"

question: What is the performance of Targeted Supervised Contrastive Learning (TSC) compared to KCL on the ImageNet-LT dataset for different class splits?
answer: According to the results reported in the paper, Targeted Supervised Contrastive Learning (TSC) achieves a test accuracy of 63.5% for many classes, 49.7% for medium classes, and 30.4% for few classes on the ImageNet-LT dataset. In comparison, KCL achieves 61.8% for many classes, 49.4% for medium classes, and 30.9% for few classes. Therefore, TSC performs better than KCL across all class splits on ImageNet-LT.
reference: Title: Targeted Supervised Contrastive Learning for Long-Tailed Recognition - Section: Experimental Results - \"\\name & \\textbf{63.5} & \\textbf{49.7} & \\textbf{30.4} & \\textbf{52.4}\"

question: How does Targeted Supervised Contrastive Learning (TSC) perform on the ImageNet-LT dataset compared to state-of-the-art methods on all classes?
answer: On the ImageNet-LT dataset, Targeted Supervised Contrastive Learning (TSC) achieves a top-1 accuracy of 52.4% on all classes, which outperforms the reported result for KCL (51.5%) as well as other baseline methods like OLTR (31.3%), $\\tau$-norm (47.9%), cRT (48.8%), and LWS (49.9%).
reference: Title: Targeted Supervised Contrastive Learning for Long-Tailed Recognition - Section: Experimental Results - \"Execution result for all classes: \\name & \\textbf{52.4}\"

question: What is the top-1 balanced accuracy improvement when RCL is added to BCL on the CIFAR100_Lt dataset with an imbalance factor of 100?
answer: When RCL is added to BCL on the CIFAR100_Lt dataset with an imbalance factor of 100, the top-1 balanced accuracy improvement is 0.2%.
reference: Title: Long-Tail Learning with Rebalanced Contrastive Loss, Reference: Section \"Performance Analysis\", \"When RCL is added to BCL, the top-1 accuracy increases by 0.2% for CIFAR100\\_Lt IF=100.\"

question: What are the Calinski-Harabasz index and Davies-Bouldin Index values for the CIFAR100_Lt dataset when using BCL+RCL compared to BCL?
answer: For the CIFAR100_Lt dataset, the Calinski-Harabasz index is 4,091.8 for BCL+RCL compared to 3,962.9 for BCL, indicating better cluster cohesion and separation. The Davies-Bouldin Index is 0.94 for BCL+RCL compared to 0.97 for BCL, indicating more compact and well-separated clusters.
reference: Title: Long-Tail Learning with Rebalanced Contrastive Loss, Reference: Section \"Embedding Space Analysis\", Table \"Feature distribution evaluation based on class density and class separation using Calinski-Harabasz index (CHI) and Davies-Bouldin Index (DBI).\"
